Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.75, 0.0] 2. Line 2: Start Point [0.75, 0.0], End Point [0.75, 0.125] 3. Line 3: Start Point [0.75, 0.125], End Point [0.25, 0.125] 4. Line 4: Start Point [0.25, 0.125], End Point [0.0, 0.125] 5. Line 5: Start Point [0.0, 0.125], End Point [0.0, 0.0] Draw the second face (face\\_2) of the prism using the following lines: 1. Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.125], End Point [0.25, 0.125] 2. Line 2: Start Point [0.25, 0.125], End Point [0.25, 0.375] 3. Line 3: Start Point [0.25, 0.375], End Point [0.25, 0.5] 4. Line 4: Start Point [0.25, 0.5], End Point [0.0, 0.5] 5. Line 5: Start Point [0.0, 0.5], End Point [0.0, 0.125] After creating the 2D sketch, scale it by the factor 0.75. Next, define the orientation of the scaled 2D sketch by specifying the euler angles [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] and the translation vector [0.0, 0.5, 0.0]. Extrude the sketch to create a 3D model with the following specifications: * Extrude depth towards normal: 0.5 * Extrude depth opposite normal: 0.0 * Sketch scale: 0.75 * Operation: Create a new body Dimension the prism with the given length 0.75, width 0.5, and height 0.75. Part 2: Three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom Create a new coordinate system with the following parameters: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.25, 0.5, 0.125] Draw the face (face\\_1) of the prism using the following lines: 1. Line 4: Start Point [0.0, 0.25], End Point [0.0, 0.0] After creating the 2D sketch, scale it by the factor 0.5. Extrude the sketch to create a 3D model with the following specifications: * Extrude depth towards normal: 0.125 * Extrude depth opposite normal: 0.0 * Sketch scale: 0.5 * Operation: Add material Dimension the second prism with the given length 0.5, width 0.125, and height 0.5. The final shape is the union of the two rectangular prisms. Note: The final shape is a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom. The front face of the prism is angled at 45 degrees. The overall dimensions of the final shape are derived from the given description.</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: Cylindrical Object with a Flat Top and Bottom, and a Center Hole Step 1: Create a new coordinate system Begin by creating a new coordinate system with no rotation or translation. Step 2: Create 2D sketch for the base of the part Create a 2D sketch on the XY-plane of the coordinate system. The sketch will have two faces: a polygonal face and a circular face. Face 1 Creating loops and curves on this face: Loop 1 - Line 1: Start Point (0.2143, 0.0), End Point (0.5357, 0.0) - Line 2: Start Point (0.5357, 0.0), End Point (0.75, 0.2143) - Line 3: Start Point (0.75, 0.2143), End Point (0.75, 0.4286) - Line 4: Start Point (0.75, 0.4286), End Point (0.2143, 0.4286) - Arc 1: Start Point (0.2143, 0.4286), Mid Point (0.0, 0.2143), End Point (0.2143, 0.0) Loop 2 - Circle 1: Center (0.2143, 0.2143), Radius 0.1071 Face 2 (Circular Face) - Circle 1: Center (0.2143, 0.2143), Radius 0.1071 Step 3: Scale the 2D sketch Scale the 2D sketch by a factor of 0.75. Step 4: Transform 2D Sketch into a 3D sketch Perform a 3D rotation using the Euler Angles [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and a translation using the vector [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]. Since there's no rotation or translation, the 2D sketch will remain parallel to the XY-plane of the coordinate system. Step 5: Extrude the 2D sketch to create the 3D model Extrude the scaled 2D sketch along the normal vector by 0.1071 units. This will create the base part of our cylindrical object. Step 6: Create the center hole Create a new coordinate system with a translation vector of [0.0, 0.0, 0.1071].
